div1.head: THE CONQUEST OF YELLOW FEVER
div1.byline:
By JAMES EDWARD PEABODY, A.M.,
Head of the Department of Biology, Morris High School, New York City
div1.p:
How many of you ever came within a thousand miles or within
two generations of yellow fever? Have any of you ever experienced
the awful terror which, with the opening of summer, formerly took
possession of many a city of our Southland? How has it come
about that within the first quarter of the present century this
disease has practically disappeared from North, South, and Central
America, and we hope soon from the whole surface of the earth?
To answer this last question we have but to review the history of
those last six months of the preceding century, so far as that his-
tory concerns the Island of Cuba.
I. THE HISTORY OF YELLOW FEVER

But first let us go back in our thoughts to those earlier days of a
hundred years ago or more and learn something of the history and
characteristics of this disease. So far as we know (Fig. 1) it first
appeared in Central America over 300 years ago, whence it was
introduced into Cuba in 1750. Across the Gulf of Mexico it came,
and the inhabitants of Charleston, Mobile, New Orleans, and
Galveston successively became its victims. Even in the more
northern cities of Baltimore, Philadelphia, New York and Boston
it wrought its havoc. In 208 years it invaded our territory 95
times, and since 1793 there have been not fewer than 100,000
deaths due to it in the United States alone.

“In the terrible epidemic of 1793 in Philadelphia,” says Miss
Hallock in her account of the life of Walter Reed, “all the streets
and roads leading from the city were crowded with families flying
to the country for safety. So many doctors were sick or had died
of yellow fever that ‘at one time there were only three physicians
who were able to visit patients, and at this time there were prob-
ably not fewer than 6,000 persons ill with the fever.’ Dr. Rush,
then a physician in Philadelphia, related that a cheerful counte-
nance was scarcely to be seen in the city for six weeks. Once on
entering the house of a poor man, he met a child of 2 years who
smiled in his face, and he says, ‘I was strangely affected by this
sight.’ Few persons were met in the streets except those who were

in quest of a physician, a nurse, or the men who buried the dead.
The hearse alone kept up the remembrance of the noise of carriages
or carts in the street.”

Previous to the yellow fever epidemic of 1878, in the City of
Memphis, Tennessee, the City had already suffered seriously from
war, reconstruction, cholera, small-pox, and two previous epi-
demics of yellow fever (in 1867 and in 1873) and in the latter year
over 2000 of the inhabitants had died. By the middle of August,
1878, it had become generally known that the dread disease had
again reached the city. “Business stopped,” says the official
report of the epidemic, “stores and offices were hastily closed.
Men, women, and children poured out of the city by every avenue
of escape... To the cities of the far north and the far west they
fled, too many of them to die on the way like dogs, neglected and
shunned as if cursed by God.

“By the last week of August it was estimated that there were
about 3000 cases of the fever... An appalling gloom hung over
the doomed city. At night it was silent as the grave, by day it
seemed desolate as the desert. There were hours, especially at
night, when the solemn oppressions of universal death bore upon
the human mind as if the day of judgment were about to dawn...
Death prevailed everywhere. Trade and traffic were suspended.
The energies of all who remained were enlisted in the struggle
with death. The poor were reduced to beggary, and even the rich
gladly accepted alms....

“On the 14th of September, the day of the heaviest mortality,
many buoyant natures succumbed. They looked about them
for convalescents, but they were not to be found; a few of them
were reported, but they seemed nearly all of them to have been
permanently disabled. The cry for food, for clothing, for money,
for doctors, for as many as a thousand coffins, went out by tele-
graph to the ends of the earth, and a prompt and generous response
came back. ...The medical estimate puts the total population,
during the epidemic, at 19,000, and the total sick at 17,600,
the deaths being 5,150, a little less than one-third.”1

Some idea of the fatalities from this disease here in the Northern
States may be gained if we call to mind the fact that in the epi-
demic of 1822 near the site of the present Wall Street, New York
City, there were 401 cases, and of these 230 (over 50%) died.
1J. M. Keating, “A History of the Yellow Fever Epidemic of 1878.”

Fig. 5. Dr. Aristides Agramonte, only liv-

mission.

Fig. 6. The Yellow Fever Mosquito. The

As one scourge followed another the doctors and government
agencies did their best to find the cause and to check the ravages
of “yellow jack.” Desperate measures of quarantine were insti-
tuted and property of great value was destroyed in these vain
attempts. Up to 1793 this disease was generally believed by peo-
ple at large to be “a visitation of God,” and all that could be hoped
for was that the frosts, which always stayed its progress, would
come early. In the treatment of yellow fever by the medical men,
however, almost every known measure under the sun had been
tried, at various times, but with little success. Even rattlesnake
poison was employed in Cuba, and some asserted it was more or
less effective. And so the last century drew to a close with the
tropics still visited by those dread epidemics.
II. THE YELLOW FEVER EXPERIMENTS IN CUBA

The Spanish-American War had ended in 1898 with the United
States in occupation of Cuba. Two years later Surgeon General
George M. Sternberg (Fig. 3) of the United States Army appointed
a Commission of four men, whose work in six short months proved
to be one of the greatest achievements of all medical history.
That Yellow Fever Commission consisted of Major Walter Reed,
M.D. (Fig. 4), Chairman, Dr. James Carroll (Fig. 10), and Dr.
Jesse Lazear (Fig. 11), none of whom had had yellow fever, and
Dr. Aristides Agramonte (Fig. 5) of Cuba, who was supposed to be
immune to the disease.

Led by Major Reed, that genius for scientific investigation, this
Commission carried through one of the most relentless series of
experiments ever devised by man. These experiments were so
conclusive that even the most stubborn doubter was forced to
agree that at last the mystery of the transmission of yellow fever
was cleared away. They demonstrated for all time that one can be
infected only by the bite of a certain kind of mosquito which had
previously bitten a yellow fever patient. This mosquito (formerly
known as Stegomyia fasciata (Fig. 6), is now called Aëdes ægypti.
But whatever its name the female of that species has been the
inciting cause of the loss of uncounted lives and of priceless prop-
erty.

Once this mosquito's culpability was demonstrated, how rela-
tively simple it has been during the last quarter of a century to
6
hunt down and exterminate the villainess, and so make tropical
countries, previously uninhabitable for man, modern health
resorts. Yellow fever is the one disease that attacks human beings
which has practically disappeared from the Western Continent and
from all but a small portion of the civilized world.

We are now to consider somewhat in detail the story of those
fateful six months from June to December, 1900. It was commonly
reported that yellow fever wrought more havoc among the Ameri-
can troops during the Spanish-American War than had Spanish
bullets,1 and once more it had begun its deadly work when the
Yellow Fever Commission arrived on the scene. Havana had
been cleaned up thoroughly under the efficient direction of General
Ludlow and General Leonard Wood (Fig. 7) and all the resources
of sanitation had been applied, but all to no purpose. Yellow
fever was more prevalent there than it had been for twenty years.

Fortunately before the last century ended Dr. Patrick Manson
and Major Ronald Ross of England had proved that malaria
can be transmitted only by the agency of a species of mos-
quito; and the common house fly had been convicted of trans-
mitting typhoid fever. Indeed, Dr. Reed himself had made gener-
ous contributions to the knowledge of the danger of flies in connec-
tion with typhoid. Many writers had for centuries called atten-
tion to the prevalence of insects during summer epidemics. So it
was not surprising that Dr. Reed soon after his arrival should
confer with a Cuban, Dr. Carlos J. Finlay (Fig. 8), who for years
had been laughed at because he had insisted that mosquitoes were
the carriers of yellow fever. Dr. Finlay's shrewd surmise, as we
now know, was correct, but he had been able to bring forward no
scientific proof that he was correct.

For the suggestion that mosquitoes might be the agent by
which yellow fever was transmitted Dr. Reed was also indebted
to a fellow worker in Cuba, who was born in the same State as Reed.
“Already one discovery had been made which at that time had at-
tracted little attention, but which, in itself, laid the foundation of

1“We had a tremendous amount of typhoid fever, malaria fever, yellow
fever, and dysentery in the Santiago campaign. I have no doubt in my own
mind that many cases reported to have died of yellow fever were in reality
typhoid or malaria. For instance, I know that the 7th. Infantry was thoroughly
disabled for any duty whatever by malaria.”--Surgeon General M. W. Ireland.
Burton J. Hendrick.

Reed's work. A year before another Virginian, Dr. Henry R.
Carter, (Fig. 35) of the Public Health Service, made an elaborate
statistical study of the spread of yellow fever in houses. ....
The observations which Carter made seem simple and obvious
enough today; yet the fact remains that it had evaded all previous
investigators, and it was the failure to observe this truth that had
caused the failure of all of Finlay's experiments.

“Carter had served many years as a quarantine officer, and
yellow fever had thus become one of the commonplace facts in his
daily existence. For many years he had observed that when a man
developed yellow fever on board ship none of his shipmates be-
came ill, even those who lived in the crowded forecastle with him,
until a time considerably in excess of the period of incubation
of the disease in man; this led him to believe that yellow fever
could not be contracted from the environment of a sick man for a
considerable time after he became sick in that environment. ....

“There seems something like the working of an intelligent fate
in the fact that the three men--Carter, Reed, and Gorgas--who
seemed indispensable to solving the yellow fever problem, were at
work at Havana at the same time. Carter was there as Quarantine
Officer, and naturally he presented his tables to his fellow Vir-
ginian. Reed gave them the most painstaking study. ‘Are you
sure your dates are accurate?’ he asked Carter. Carter had no
doubt on that point. ‘Then,’ said Reed, ‘it spells an insect host.’
...It was one thing to form this conception but quite a different
thing to demonstrate it. And the way proved almost as difficult
for Reed as for Finlay.”1

Trained by Dr. William H. Welch in the Johns Hopkins Hos-
pital, Baltimore, Dr. Reed set to work to test Dr. Finlay's and Dr.
Carter's theory. Dr. Lazear was put in charge of mosquito breed-
ing; Dr. Carroll hunted for possible bacteria that might be the
cause of the disease; while Dr. Agramonte studied the bodies of
those who had died of yellow fever. So there were two lines of in-
vestigation in which the Commission was engaged--the hunt for
the bacterial cause of the disease, and the means by which these
germs were transmitted from the sick to the new victims. The
first proved to be unfruitful; not so the second.

1“William Crawford Gorgas.--His Life and Work” by Marie D. Gorgas and
Burton J. Hendrick.

A hundred miles from Havana there was an epidemic of yellow
fever. Thither went Dr. Reed on the last day of July, 1900. He
found that many of those who had been in contact with the cloth-
ing and bed linen of the yellow fever victims had not taken the
disease. This led him to question the common belief in those
mysterious contagious “fomites” (clothing, furniture, food) which
were supposed to be the source of infection. On the other hand
a prisoner in the guard-house, who had no possible opportunity
of contact with either a case of yellow fever or fomites did acquire
it. These facts gave rise to the conjecture that “perhaps some
insect capable of conveying the infection, such as the mosquito,”
might have been the means by which the disease was carried.

To test this theory it was necessary that experiments be made on
human beings, for all attempts to produce yellow fever in guinea
pigs, rabbits, monkeys and other animals had failed. Was such a
dangerous series of experiments justifiable? was the question.
The members of the Commission sought to find out by apply-
ing the mosquitoes to themselves. Dr. Lazear hatched out
mosquitoes from eggs furnished by Dr. Finlay, allowed them to
bite yellow fever patients, and then let them bite himself. The
result was negative, for no one knew at that time the length of
time that must elapse before the yellow fever organism within the
mosquito would become capable of causing the disease.

Near the end of August Dr. Lazear applied to Dr. Carroll (Fig.
10) a mosquito he had hatched in the laboratory. This insect had
been allowed to bite at different intervals four yellow fever pa-
tients. Four days later Dr. Carroll was down with yellow fever,
and for three days his life was despaired of. Fortunately he re-
covered, but six years later the heart of this brave doctor, weakened
by the idsease to which he had voluntarily exposed himself, ceased
to beat.

Dr. Lazear (Fig. 11) continued his stern experimentations during
the illness of Dr. Carroll. While he was collecting blood from a
yellow fever patient, a mosquito settled on his hand and he allowed
it to take its fill. In a few days he, too, was ill with the disease
in its most deadly form, and within a week died in delirium. His
death was an irreparable loss to the Commission.

Dr. Reed, deeply sorrowful though he was for the illness of Dr.
Carroll and depressed by the death of Dr. Lazear, felt confident

Fig. 9. Dr. Alvah H. Doty, PostHealth Officer Port of of
New York.
Fig. 10. Dr. James Carroll.
Fig. 11. Dr. Jesse W. Lazear.
Fig. 12. John R. Kissinger (1900).

10
that much had been accomplished in the two and a half months
since the Commission had begun its work. He was convinced in
his own mind that the long sought solution of the problem had
been found. He was too wise, however, not to know that a
skeptical world would still raise all sorts of objections to his
conclusions. “How do you know,” they would say, “that Dr.
Carroll and Dr. Lazear had not been infected before the mos-
quitoes bit them?” “How do you know they had not come in
contact with those deadly ‘fomites’ that are, we are sure, the cause
of this disease?” And so this quiet, determined Doctor set him-
self to devise experiments that would be absolutely convincing.

They were talking over these plans after the death of Dr.
Lazear--the three remaining members of the Commission--and a
hospital orderly who had served through the Spanish-American
War overheard them; John R. Kissinger was his name. (Fig. 12).
“We must have more human beings to experiment on,” he heard
them say. He crept away into the silence of the laboratory to
think it over. “I volunteered for the war to be killed if necessary,”
he said to himself; “why should not I volunteer for this service
also?” So he came to Major Reed and brought with him an old
friend of the same Ohio regiment, John J. Moran. (Fig. 24).
“We are ready, sir,” they said.

But Dr. Reed knew all too well the dangers that faced them, and
he made this clear to them in no uncertain terms. These men had
themselves seen soldier after soldier carried out from the yellow
fever hospitals feet first to be buried in the coffins that had awaited
them. The two, however, were still fixed in their determination.
Dr. Reed then offered them money for their services, which they
promptly refused. “We do this,” said Kissinger, “solely in the
interests of science and the cause of humanity.” Thereupon
Major Reed touched his cap, saying, “Gentlemen, I salute you.”
Later, when Major Reed sent in his report to Washington officials,
he said of the offer of Moran and Kissinger, “In my opinion, this
exhibition of moral courage has never been surpassed in the
annals of the Army of the United States.”

The stage was now set for those grim performances which in two
short months demonstrated beyond a doubt that the belief of old
Dr. Finlay and of Dr. Carter was absolutely correct. About a
mile from Quemados, Cuba, in a lonely, uncultivated field an experi-

mental station had been established. It was open to sun and air,
but carefully closed against any possible outside infection. They
named it Camp Lazear in honor of their fellow member who had
given his life a martyr to the cause. Here they had erected seven
hospital tents, and on November 20th this camp was put under the
strictest quarantine. To it came the brave volunteers who were
to be experimented upon, but no one else was permitted to enter or
leave the place except the immune attendants who went for sup-
plies to the neighboring Columbia Barracks. Every non-immune
inmate of the camp was carefully examined three times daily as to
temperature and pulse rate, so that every infected individual could
at once be removed from the experiment station.

Full two weeks of possible danger had passed and all the in-
mates were in healthy condition. Now began the deadly experi-
ments. On December 5th, at 2 o'clock in the afternoon they took
five promising mosquitoes which had bitten yellow fever patients,
and with Kissinger's free consent these mosquitoes settled down
upon him and drank their fill of his blood. “On the night of
December 8th,” says Kissinger, “at 11:30 I was taken with a chill
that lasted approximately 20 minutes. I lit a candle, and with a
thermometer took my temperature. It showed 100 degrees. The
guard asked why the light and what the trouble was. I told him to
call Dr. Ames who came in less than five minutes. By that time I
was nauseated and felt like I had been kicked like a football, the
pains in my back and muscles were so severe. I was taken to
yellow fever quarters. The chart (Fig. 13) will show my temper-
ature during the 3rd and 4th day.”

On December 9th. Dr. Reed wrote to his wife as follows: “It is
with a great deal of pleasure that I hasten to tell you that we have
succeeded in producing a case of unmistakable yellow fever by the
bite of the mosquito. Our first case in the experimental camp
developed at 11:30 last night with a sudden chill followed by fever.
He had been bitten on December 5th, and hence his attack followed
just three and a half days after the bite. As he had been in our
camp 15 days before being inoculated and had had no other pos-
sible exposure, the case is as clear as the noonday, and sustains
brilliantly and conclusively our conclusions. Thus just 18 days
from the time we began our experimental work we have succeeded
in demonstrating this mode of propagation of the disease, so that
13
the most doubtful and skeptical must yield. Rejoice, with me,
sweetheart, as aside from the antitoxin of diphtheria and Koch's
discovery of the tubercle bacillus, it will be regarded as the most
important piece of work scientifically during the nineteenth cen-
tury. I do not exaggerate, and I could shout for joy that heaven
has permitted me to establish this wonderful way of propagating
yellow fever. It was Finlay's theory, and he deserves great credit
for having suggested it, but as he did nothing to prove it, it was
rejected by all, including General Sternberg. Now we have put it
beyond a cavil, and its importance to Cuba and the United States
cannot be estimated. Major J. R. Kean (Fig. 14) says that the
discovery is worth more than the cost of the Spanish-American
War, including lives lost and money expended. He is almost
beside himself with joy and will tell General Wood when he goes to
town in the morning. . . . 9:30 P.M. Since writing the above
our patient has been doing well. His temperature, which was 102.5
degrees at noon, has fallen to 101 degrees and his severe headache
and backache have subsided considerably. Everything points, so
far as it can at this stage, to a favorable termination, for which I
feel so happy.”

This experiment, conclusive as it was, was only one of that
gruesome series carried out at Camp Lazear by Major Reed. He
must determine whether or not “fomites” could cause yellow
fever. This he did in the following way. A small wooden building
(14 × 20 feet) was erected near the hospital tents (Fig. 16). It had
two tiny windows, both facing south, guarded with wire screens.
Heavy wooden shutters kept out the sunlight, and anything like
thorough ventilation was impossible. Double screen doors insured
the interior against the invasion of mosquitoes. A coal oil stove
with pans of evaporating water kept at the temperature up to
92° to 95° and provided the humidity of our most uncomfortable
dog-day. These surely were ideal conditions in which to develop
yellow fever!

“On November 30th,” says Dr. Reed, “the building now being
ready for occupation (Fig. 15), three large boxes filled with sheets,
pillowslips, blankets, etc., contaminated by contact with cases of
yellow fever and their discharges were received and placed there.
The majority of the articles had been taken from the beds of
patients sick with yellow fever at Las Animas Hospital, Havana, or
14
at Columbia Barracks. Many of them had been purposely soiled
with a liberal quantity of human excretions. . . . The same day
at 6 P.M., Dr. Robert P. Cooke, Acting Assistant Surgeon U.S.A.,
and two privates of the hospital corps, Folk and Jernegan, (Fig. 17)
all non-immune young Americans, entered this building and
deliberately unpacked these boxes, which had been tightly closed
and locked for a period of two weeks. They were careful at the
same time to give each article a thorough handling and shaking in
order to disseminate through the air of the room the specific agent
of yellow fever, if contained in these fomites. These soiled sheets,
pillow-cases, and blankets were used in preparing the beds in which
the members of the hospital corps slept. Various soiled articles were
hung around the room and placed about the bed occupied by Dr.
Cooke.

“From this date until December 19th. a period of 20 days, this
room was occupied each night by these three non-immunes. Each
morning the various soiled articles were carefully packed in the
aforesaid boxes, and at night again unpacked and distributed about
the room. During the day the residents of this house were per-
mitted to occupy a tent pitched in the immediate vicinity, but
were kept in strict quarantine.

“December 12th. a fourth box of clothing and bedding was re-
ceived from Las Animas Hospital. These articles had been used
on the beds of yellow fever patients, but in addition had been pur-
posely soiled from a fatal case of the disease. As this box had been
packed for a number of days, when it was opened and unpacked by
Dr. Cooke and his assistants on December 12, the odour was so
offensive as to compel them to retreat from the house. They
pluckily returned, however, within a short time and spent the night
as usual.

“On December 19th. these three non-immunes were placed in
quarantine for five days, and then given the liberty of the camp.
All had remained in perfect health, notwithstanding their stay
of twenty nights amid such unwholesome surroundings.” “To
pass twenty nights,” says Dr. Kelly in his “Walter Reed and Yel-
low Fever,” “in a small, ill-ventilated room with the temperature
over ninety, in close contact with the most loathsome articles of
dress and furniture, in an atmosphere fetid from their presence, is
an act of heroism which ought to command our highest admiration
and our lasting gratitude.”

During the month since Camp Lazear was opened two great
findings had been established beyond a shadow of a doubt: first,
that yellow fever can be caused by the bite of infected mosquitoes
of a certain species; and secondly, that this disease cannot result
from contact with the clothing or the discharges from yellow fever
patients. “We must now prove,” said Major Reed, “that this
disease can be transmitted only by the bites of these mosquitoes.”
Only a genius for scientific work could have devised this final and
clinching experiment.

Another little hut had been built (Fig. 18) similar to the “in-
fected clothing building,” except that it was light, and clean, and
airy, and had been completely divided into two compartments by
a permanent wire screen. The only articles of furniture were
three cot beds, one being placed in the larger compartment, and
two on the other side of the wire screen. Everything had been
carefully disinfected by steam, and this little house with its admi-
rable ventilation would have been a perfect place, before the experi-
ment began, for any out-door hospital patient.

Four days before Christmas they let loose fifteen mosquitoes in
the larger of the two rooms. These had fed on yellow fever
patients at varying intervals during the preceding days. At noon,
into this “infected mosquito room,” came Kissinger's fellow volun-
teer, John J. Moran1, (Fig. 24) clad only in his night shirt. He lay

Havana, not far from the scene of the experiments of 1900, the writer describes
his experiences as follows. “The first attempt to inoculate me was made on

in a test tube being employed on each occasion and returned to captivity
after feeding on my blood. Results in both cases were NIL. Doctor Reed
then decided to save me for his master test in the “Infected Mosquito Build-
ing.” Infected mosquitoes in sufficient number were not available until
December 21st., 1900, when fifteen of the insects were freed in the building.
These mosquitoes had bitten severe cases of yellow fever from five to twenty-
four days before. Five minutes later, that is to say at 12 o'clock noon on
December 21st., I offered a feast to the fifteen guests which was promptly
partaken of by eight. With the aid of a hand mirror I watched them gorge
themselves. In the afternoon of the same day and at the same hour of the
following afternoon, the remaining seven had their fill. Doctor Reed told me
that if this test should prove successful the mosquito theory would be estab-
lished in fool-proof fashion, and that the sceptics would not have a leg to
stand on. The sceptics were many in number and most of them prominent in
the medical profession.
“On December 25th., 1900 (Christmas morning) I awakened to the fact

down upon the cot, and seven of the hungry mosquitoes settled
down upon him and bit him about his face and hands. A second
and third time he exposed himself to the bites of the other eight
tormentors.

On Christmas morning this brave lad was stricken with yellow
fever and bore his sharp attack without a murmur. Since Moran
had been kept in strict quarantine for 32 days prior to the experi-
ment, was it not perfectly evident that he caught his yellow fever
from the infected mosquitoes? Further proof of this fact was pre-
sented by the two non-immunes who had occupied the cots on the
other side of the screen: they remained perfectly well throughout
the experiment, in spite of the fact that they had breathed the
same air as Moran. From this interlocking series of fool-proof
demonstrations Dr. Reed and all those about him reached the
absolute certainty that yellow fever is always and everywhere trans-
mitted by infected mosquitoes, and by mosquitoes alone. No wonder
he wrote to his wife with profound thankfulness the following
letter: (Fig. 19).

“Columbia Barracks, Quemados, Cuba,
11:50 P.M., Dec. 31, 1900.

“Only ten minutes of the old century remain. Here have I been
sitting, reading that most wonderful book, ‘LaRoche on Yellow
Fever,’ written in 1853. Forty-seven years later it has been per-
mitted to me and my assistants to lift the impenetrable veil that
has surrounded the causation of this most wonderful, dreadful pest
of humanity and to put it on a rational and scientific basis. I
thank God that this has been accomplished during the latter days
of the old century. May its cure be wrought out in the early days
of the new! The prayer that has been mine for twenty years that
I might be permitted in some way or at some time to alleviate

that one of the fifteen insects had done its duty, and I knew that I would
be on my way to the yellow fever camp hospital before many hours. Doctor
Reed did not visit the experimental camp until afternoon on Christmas day,
and by the time he arrived my temperature, which I was taking and recording
every hour, had risen to over 103 degrees Fahrenheit. I was packed off in
an ambulance and by midnight my temperature rose to within a fraction of 105.
Dr. Reed and his associates pronounced my attack ‘a very pretty case.’ . . .
In ten days I was up and around and three days later I took the blood test
(from the veins of a case of yellow fever) to see if I was immune. I was. It
had no effect on me.”
Fig. 17. Warren G. Jernegan.
Fig. 18. Infected mosquito building.

Fig. 19. Dr. Reed's letter to his wife,--
December 31, 1900.

U.S.A.

18
human suffering has been granted! A thousand Happy New
Years. . . . Hark, there go the twenty-four buglers in concert, all
sounding ‘Taps’ for the old year.”

At one time during the experiments “infected mosquitoes were
scarce; in fact, Dr. Reed had only one to give his co-workers--a
mosquito so venerable and precious that she was popularly known
as ‘Her Ladyship.’ A more vicious beast than ‘Her Ladyship’
probably never inhabited this earth; she had given many persons
yellow fever, and for fifty-seven days she had carried the germ
until her body was little more than an animated culture tube
of the disease; yet few patients have been more tenderly cared for.
Her home was a large glass jar on the table in the center of a
sunshiny room; an oil stove, especially brought from the United
States, kept her apartment at just the desired temperature.
But ‘Her Ladyship’ soon began to behave in a most discouraging
fashion.

“One morning about daylight,” writes Gorgas, “I got a message
saying that ‘Her Ladyship’ was in a most critical and desperate
plight. At some time during the night she had caught her wing in
a mesh of the mosquito netting, and had struggled to free herself
for so long a time that when she was discovered by the attendant
in the morning, she was almost dead. I rapidly dressed and
hurried to the hospital. Similar messages had been sent to Dr.
Ross and Dr. Guiteras. We found her condition even worse than
had been represented. Two or three of the doctors on the staff
of the hospital had been promptly called in, and the services of
several of our trained nurses had been likewise obtained. Her
wing had been gently liberated from the mesh of the netting,
and ‘Her Ladyship’ laid on a soft bed of cotton batting. The oil
stove was started up, and the room brought to a very hot summer
temperature, but it was all of no avail. She finally ceased to
kick, about nine o'clock in the morning, and died with a larger
attendance of doctors and nurses around her table than had ever
been present around the deathbed of any mere human in the
City of Havana.”1

1“William Crawford Gorgas.--His Life and Work,” by Marie D. Gorgas
and Burton J. Hendrick.
III. RESULTS OF THE YELLOW FEVER EXPERIMENTS

Once the key to the mystery of the method of transmission of
a disease has been discovered, the way to fight it usually becomes
clear. Certainly this proved to be true in the case of yellow
fever. Fortunately Cuba had as its Military Governor that intel-
ligent and resourceful Major-General, Leonard Wood. He had
followed with absorbing interest Major Reed's experiments, and
in this work he had given his assistance unstintingly. He now
proceeded to put into practice this new found knowledge. Dr.
Reed's own account of the final conquest of yellow fever in Cuba
is as follows:

“The importance of the discovery that yellow fever is trans-
mitted by the bite of a certain species of mosquito did not fail to
attract the prompt attention of the military governor of Cuba,
himself a physician, and formerly a distinguished member of the
Medical Department of the United States Army. By his direction
the theory was subjected to a practical test in the city of Havana,
in which city yellow fever had not failed to make its yearly ap-
pearance during the past one hundred and forty years.

“Under the efficient management of the chief officer, Surgeon-
Major William Gorgas, U. S. A. (Fig. 20) (of whom we shall hear
more later) the sanitary regulations were so far modified as to
require that every patient having yellow fever should not only be
quarantined, but that his room should be promptly protected with
wire screens, so as to prevent the possibility of mosquitoes becom-
ing infected by sucking the blood of the patient. As a second im-
portant measure, a systematic destruction of all mosquitoes in
other rooms of the patient's house, as well as in adjoining houses,
was at once begun, the fumes of pyrethrum being relied upon to
stupefy the insects, after which they were carefully swept up and
buried. In other words, Surgeon-Major Gorgas, relying upon the
well-known slow progress of yellow fever, sought to destroy all
mosquitoes, infected or non-infected, within a given radius of each
case, while at the same time he effectually excluded all mosquitoes
from access to the sick1....
“As an illustration of what has been accomplished by these newer

1“At the same time the breeding of mosquitoes was prevented by removing
all deposits of water in and about the buildings or pouring kerosene on them.”
--Col. J. R. Kean.

sanitary regulations, I may say that, counting from the date when
they were put in force, viz., February 15, 1901, Havana was freed
from yellow fever within ninety days; so that from May 7 to July 1,
a period of fifty-four days, no cases occurred. Notwithstanding
the fact that on the latter date and during the months of July,
August, and September, the disease was repeatedly reintroduced
into Havana from an inland town, no difficulty was encountered in
promptly stamping it out, by the same measures of sanitation,
intelligently applied, both in the city of Havana and in the town
of Santiago de las Vegas, whence the disease was being brought
into Havana.” Major J. R. Kean, after Dr. Reed's death added
the following statement: “Not a single case of yellow fever occurred
in Havana during the year 1902, nor, so far as known, in the Island
of Cuba.”

Some time before the Yellow Fever Commission began its work
Dr. Alvah H. Doty (Fig. 9) had become Health Officer Port of New
York. He was charged with the important duty of examining
at the Quarantine Office all incoming ships and passengers and of
isolating any persons who had contagious diseases. For some
time he had been pondering over the source of yellow fever infec-
tion, and from his previous experience as City Health Officer he
had reached the conclusion that lifeless material like clothing or
food supplies could not transmit yellow fever. When the time came
for bringing back the soldiers from Cuba, Dr. Doty was so con-
vinced that he was right that he offered to assume the responsi-
bility for admitting the troops through the Port of New York. His
offer was gladly accepted by the National Government. When,
however, he refused to fumigate the ships and the clothing of
passengers a storm of protest broke about his head, especially from
the inhabitants of the Southern States. At the height of this
indignation came the triumphant demonstrations made by the
Reed Commission which completely vindicated our Port Officer.

In Laredo, Texas, a city of 18,000 inhabitants, yellow fever
broke out in 1903. Water in the town was commonly stored in
barrels. No better place could be devised for breeding the Aëdes
mosquitoes, and investigation showed that they were present in
enormous numbers. The poorer classes lived in houses of the
worst type, mere shacks of adobe and boards, and so the methods
of disinfection of houses and care of the sick that had proved so
21
successful in Havana were difficult to apply in Laredo. The epi-
demic increased so rapidly, however, that a complete disinfection
of the whole city, and widespread war on mosquitoes was begun.
In this the sanitary authorities were constantly hampered, since
they had nothing like the military backing that was so effective in
Cuba. In spite of these handicaps, however, the disease was
finally eradicated completely.

New Orleans suffered seriously from yellow fever in 1905. For-
tunately here the citizens appealed to the Public Health and
Marine Hospital Service to take charge of the situation. When
this national organization arrived on the scene, there had been 616
cases and 112 deaths. On a single day, August 12th, there were
reported 105 new cases. The citizens, however, had complete
confidence in the measures that were instituted, and cooperated
heartily. Placards were distributed by the thousand bearing the
words “Wear a Smile on Your Face and a Flower in Your But-
tonhole.” What a contrast between this situation and the hope-
less terror in the Philadelphia epidemic of a century before.
None of the New Orleans population fled from the city,
food and clothing did not need to be inspected or destroyed, and
the citizens went hopefully about their business. Yellow fever
ceased to exist in the city early in November. There was no need
to wait anxiously for the frosts; the only thing necessary was to
hunt down and destroy remorselessly the Aëdes mosquito. What
a debt we owe to Dr. Reed, Surgeon-Major Gorgas and their
associates!

Now comes the story of our national triumph in building the
Panama Canal. The French had tried it, and doubtless would
have accomplished it had not the toll of death from yellow fever
and malaria made the task hopeless. In 1904 Surgeon-Major
Gorgas (Fig. 20) came to Panama, as Chief Sanitary Officer. His
experience in Havana had made him an ardent advocate of Dr.
Reed's conclusions, and those same methods of disinfection and of
mosquito extermination were put into practice in the Canal Zone.
The Canal Construction Commission became critical and un-
sympathetic, but Gorgas doggedly worked on. Trees and brush
were cleared away and swamps were drained along the sides of the
course of the Canal, and so mosquito breeding places disappeared
one by one. Discouragements there were aplenty, but within two
22
years the fight was won. Yellow fever had disappeared from
Panama. Malaria, too, is a mosquito borne disease, and the sick-
ness and death rate from this disease was cut down tremendously.

So the fight against the Aëdes mosquito (Fig. 6) has gone on
during the past quarter of a century. Wherever yellow fever has
appeared, about the Caribbean Sea, in Mexico, Central or South
America, there the sanitary brigades have relentlessly pursued the
insects. The Rockefeller Foundation has organized and largely
financed this work, its beneficent aim being that of eradicating
yellow fever from the face of the earth. All prospects now point
toward final and complete success. Dr. George E. Vincent,
President of the Foundation, reports that during 1925 only three
cases of the disease were reported in all the Western Hemisphere,
and it is not quite certain that all three were genuine cases. In
1926 there was it is true in Brazil a local “flare up” of the disease,
but this is likely soon to be stamped out. (Fig. 21).

In 1918, during a yellow fever outbreak in Ecuador, Dr. Hideyo
Noguchi, (Fig. 23) a brilliant Japanese member of the Rockefeller
Institute, (Fig. 22) began an investigation, later extended to
other South and Central American countries, with a view to
isolating the causative germ of the disease. From some of the
cases in Ecuador and elsewhere in South America, he obtained an
organism (Leptospira icteroides) which proved to be closely allied
to the one which causes infectious jaundice, a disease very much
like yellow fever.

Dr. Noguchi's work in South and Central America was con-
firmed by others, but in West Africa the Leptospira germ could
not be found, although the yellow fever of that region had been
regarded as the same disease as the yellow fever of South America.
This fact gave rise to doubt as to the relationship of Noguchi's
leptospira to yellow fever, and led Dr. Noguchi himself to go to
West Africa to study yellow fever there.

Just as Dr. Noguchi was ready to return to America, he was
stricken with yellow fever, and died of this disease May 21st
1928--another hero-martyr in a great cause. Two other members
of the laboratory group of scientists on the west coast of Africa
had likewise lost their lives from yellow fever within a year--Dr.
Adrian Stokes, September 19th, 1927 (Fig. 37) and Dr. W. A.
Young, May 29th., 1928 (Fig. 38), both of them young English-

men. Dr. Howard B. Cross, (Fig. 36) who was a pupil of Dr.
Noguchi, while studying yellow fever at Vera Cruz, died of this
disease December 26th, 1921. There are few diseases which science
has fought so successfully that are so dangerous to the scientists
engaged in the campaign, as is yellow fever.

IV. LATER HISTORY OF THE YELLOW FEVER HEROES
OF 1900

But what of the later history of those heroes of that fateful year
of 1900--those men to whom the whole world owes such a lasting
debt of gratitude? Dr. Lazear had laid down his life in Cuba, and
Dr. Carroll had but six short years to live. Back from Cuba came
Dr. Reed, (Fig. 25) wearied and weakened by those months of
unremitting toil. In the following year he had a severe attack of
appendicitis. As he was placed on the operating table he said to
his old friend, Major Kean to whom he was much attached, “Kean,
I am not afraid of the knife, but if anything should happen to me,
I am leaving my wife and daughter so little;” and when he went
under the influence of the ether, he was heard to whisper, “so
little, so little.” He died six days after the operation, and his
body now rests on a beautiful hill-top in Arlington Cemetery.
(Fig. 26). Upon his tombstone is this inscription, “He gave to man
control over that dreadful scourge, yellow fever.”

What has our country done thus far to honor these heroes of
Cuba or their memory? After years of delay Congress grudgingly
passed a bill which gave to Mrs. Reed (Fig. 27), Mrs. Carroll, Mrs.
Lazear and Mrs. Jernegan an annual pension of $1500. “So
little, so little,” whispered Dr. Reed as his life ebbed out. In
all these years of the rising cost of living there has been no increase
in this yearly stipend, and, hardest of all for these widows to en-
dure, no Congressional vote of thanks.

Private Jernegan, after his twenty-day experience in the “in-
fected clothing” building, twice offered himself to mosquito infec-
tion, but still escaped the disease. When, however, Dr. Reed
needed a victim into whose veins he might inject the blood of a
yellow fever patient, Jernegan submitted to this test. Fortu-
nately he recovered from his sharp illness, and later with his wife
and son spent eight years in the Panama Canal Zone when help

Museum, Washington. Inscription on card,
“In reverendt memory of Major Walter Reed
who gave to us teachers, to teach our stu-
dents, that incomparable story of heroism”
from the New York Association of Biology
Teachers.

Fig. 26. Dr. Reed's grave in Arlington
Cemetery.
Fig. 27. Mrs. Walter Reed.

Fig. 28. Mr. and Mrs. Kissinger supporting
themselves by taking in washings.

there was greatly needed. He died in February, 1922, and his
body now lies in a little cemetery beside a railroad track in Spartan-
burg, S. C. Should not our country which owes such debts of
gratitude to Private Warren G. Jernegan, at least see that the long-
ing of his widow to have her hero's body lie in Arlington Cemetery
among the nation's dead be satisfied?

Even more cruel has been our country's treatment of Kissinger.
When the Yellow Fever Commission was ceasing its work, he re-
turned to the States broken in health. Still trying to ‘carry
on’ Kissinger in 1907 was returning from his work in a box factory
in South Bend, Indiana, when he fell in the streets and became
paralyzed from his waist down. Those were black days in the
Kissinger home. With no income other than a paltry $12 a
month from the Government, Mrs. Kissinger heroically took up
her burden. She nursed her husband, and took in ten to fourteen
washings a week. “We had no other way to live,” she said.

Later Kissinger slowly recovered the use of his body; he could
crawl about the house on specially constructed heavy leather knee
coverings (Fig. 29); then he could sit in a wheel chair (Fig. 30),
and propped up with pillows, he would help with the washings by
turning the wringer (Fig. 28). Things began to look a bit brighter,
too, from another direction. After a long fight in Congress, an
additional pension of $100 a month was secured. One hundred
and twelve dollars a month was fairly satisfactory for a few years.

Then came the Great War with mounting cost of living and with
increasing cost of sickness. To fill their cup of misery there came
in 1922 from the Pension Bureau in Washington a letter
which stated that Kissinger had no right to receive the two pen-
sions that had been paid to him since 1911 ($12 and $100 a month).
Demand was made upon him that he return at once the sum of
$1699.60. Congress did hasten to pass a special act which freed
him from this repayment. Up to the present moment, however, he
receives but $100 a month. The Kissingers had been living in a
poorly built rented house (Fig. 31) in the little town of Andrews,
Indiana (where the rent was cheap), and winters especially they
had suffered from the cold and from lack of bodily comforts.
Frequent illnesses, too, had made heavy drains, on their resources.
In spite of all these years of suffering and neglect, this hero said
when we visited him in September, 1926, “I would do it all over
again if it were necessary.”
Fig. 29. Kissinger with his knee coverings.
Fig. 30. Kissinger in his wheel chair.

Fig. 31. Former home of the Kissingers in
Andrews, Indiana.

Fig. 32. Kissinger's “Dream Home,” Hunt-
ington, Indiana.

Fig. 33. Extract from a letter written to
the author in 1912.

Fig. 34. Surgeon General Merritt W. Ire-
land, U. S. A.

In November, 1926, the New York Association of Biology
Teachers, learning of the needs of the Kissingers, hastened to
send them a substantial sum of money. This was most gratefully
received and acknowledged. It helped them to buy needed winter
clothing and fuel. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, in a sermon
preached in February of the following year (1927), sent out upon
the air Kissinger's story and that of the other victims of the yel-
low fever experiments. The response was immediate. A Com-
mittee of the Biology Association and a Citizens' Committee headed
by Dr. Fosdick were formed; newspaper and magazine publicity
was generously given; and funds began to come in. Sufficient has
been secured to purchase a very comfortable six room house, nearly
three acres of land, farm implements, a cow and some poultry
(Fig. 32). At last this servant of humanity has for his own the
home he had longed for these many years, and the expressions of
gratitude from the Kissingers are touching. May they live long
and enjoy their “Dream Home” as a partial compensation for what
they have suffered.
V. OUR DEBT TO THE HEROES OF MEDICINE

No story in all the history of scientific achievement seems to
make stronger appeal to young people than does this dramatic tale
of the conquest of yellow fever. Must it continue to be told with
no answering response from the country at large? Not if the
teachers and students throughout the length and breadth of the
land will but band together and act. Congress is always anxious
to do what the people of the country wish. It does not, however,
and it cannot know what is wanted unless the people present
their wishes in a manner that is compelling. Several bills to
give something like adequate pensions to the widows of the three
doctors and to the other yellow fever heroes were introduced
during the 1927-1928 sessions of Congress, but they failed to
become law because of this lack of crystallized public interest.

“Precedents are abundant,” says Major (now Colonel) Kean,
“for state aid to public benefactors and their families. The English
Government a century ago, when the purchasing power of money
was far greater than at present, gave to Jenner, the discoverer of
vaccination, grants amounting to £30,000. He also received
£7,383 from a subscription in India. Pasteur, the founder of the
29
science of bacteriology, besides numerous honors and money dona-
tions from other sources, received from the French Government a
pension of 12,000 francs. Lister, the originator of antiseptic
surgery, has, besides numerous honors and decorations, been
successively knighted and elevated to the peerage”.

In the autumn of 1926 Colonel Kean suggested a pension of
$3,000 a year for each of the three widows and for the Kissingers.
This plan was heartily supported by Surgeon General Ireland
(Fig. 34) of the Army, by Surgeon-General Cumming of the Public
Health Service, and by many other Washington officials. Every
Senator and Member of Congress whose attention was called
to this opportunity seemed to favor it. But Congress is a large
body, its members are widely scattered, and they represent regions
of the country that have widely divergent interests. While the
bill received the unanimous approval of the Committee on Military
Affairs of the House of Representatives, it failed of passage during
the closing hours of the session. A new bill will be introduced
in the Senate and the House early in December, 1928 providing
for a special gold medal for all the twenty-three heroes of those
memorable experiments, and increased pensions for those who
specially need them.

As indicated above, Congress cannot be expected to pass legis-
lation, even as worthy as this, unless it can feel that it is spending
the people's money as the people wish it spent.

It is not yet too late however for us to take our place with
England and France as a nation that delights to honor those who
have saved us from the horrors of a loathsome disease. We
have been paying the highest of official honors to the avaitors
who have spanned the seas. Shall we do less for the survivors
and their families of those harrowing but triumphant experiments
of 1900, which taught us to rid the earth of one of its worst pesti-
lences?

REVIEW QUESTIONS ON YELLOW FEVER

list.item:
1. Where did yellow fever first appear in the Western Hemi-
sphere? When did it reach Cuba? Trace its course northward
from Cuba.

2. Give an account of the Philadelphia epidemic of 1793; of the
New York epidemic of 1822; of the Memphis epidemic of 1878.

3. What are some of the earlier methods of combating this
disease?

4. When was the Yellow Fever Commission appointed, and by
whom? Name the members of this Commission.

5. State several respects in which the work of this Commission
was very remarkable.

6. What was the situation in Havana when the Commission
arrived on the scene?

7. Discuss the scientific and practical contributions made before
1900 by Drs. Manson and Ross of England, Dr. Finlay of Havana,
and Dr. Doty, Port Officer of New York.

8. What line of investigation was undertaken by each of the
members of the Yellow Fever Commission. Which line of investi-
gation proved to be fruitful, and which was soon abandoned?

9. How was Dr. Reed led to doubt the possibility of the trans-
mission of this disease by clothing and other lifeless objects (fo-
mites)?

10. Why was it necessary to try experiments on human beings?
Why did the earlier experiments fail?

11. Give an account of the first attack of “experimental yellow
fever.”
12. Describe Dr. Lazear's illness and death.
13. Why was it necessary to carry on further experiments?

14. How did Moran and Kissinger come to volunteer for these
experiments? Give an account of Major Reed's interview with
these two men.

15. Describe the preparation of Camp Lazear for Dr. Reed's
experiments. How were the inmates of this camp protected from
accidental infection?

16. Tell the story of Kissinger's attack of experimental yellow
fever.

17. How did Dr. Reed prove that yellow fever cannot be trans-
32
mitted by clothing? What further experiments were tried on
Private Jernegan?

18. Describe the experiments which demonstrated that this
disease can be transmitted only by the bite of an infected Aedes
Egypti mosquito?

19. Why was it fortunate that the sanitation of Cuba was in
charge of such men as General Leonard Wood and Major (later
Colonel) Kean?

20. How did Surgeon-Major Gorgas make practical application
of the discoveries of Dr. Reed? What was the result in Havana in
one year?

21. Give an account of the epidemic of 1903 in Laredo, Texas.
Contrast this epidemic with that which occurred in New Orleans
two years later.

22. Show how the truimphant experiments carried on in Cuba
made possible the building of the Panama Canal.

23. Give an account of the work of the Rockefeller Foundation
in helping to eradicate yellow fever from the world.

24. Tell the story of Dr. Reed and Dr. Carroll after the experi-
ments in Cuba were over.

25. What sufferings has Private John R. Kissinger undergone
during the past twenty-seven years?

26. Do you think our Government has thus far (1928) shown in
any adequate way the gratitude of our Country and of the whole
world to those who were responsible for the Conquest of Yellow
Fever? Give as many reasons as you can for your answer.

27. How have England and France shown their gratitude for
the work done by their men of science?

28. What can you do to help discharge the debt we all owe to
those Yellow Fever Heroes of 1900?
